title: Choledocholithiasis
diagnosis_topic: Common bile duct stones causing biliary obstruction without infection
setup_script: A 50-year-old woman presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain and jaundice. She has a prior history of gallstones but no surgeries.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 125/80 mmHg, HR 96 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 37.2 C.
Elevated bilirubin 3.5 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 250 U/L, AST/ALT mildly elevated, amylase normal.
Gallbladder with stones and common bile duct 9 mm diameter but no definitive stone seen.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders MRCP or EUS
dynamic_flow.reply: Reveals 6 mm stone in distal common bile duct causing obstruction.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident starts IV fluids and analgesia
If resident consults gastroenterology for ERCP
dynamic_flow.reply: Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone extraction performed successfully.
Obstruction may progress to cholangitis or pancreatitis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident plans interval laparoscopic cholecystectomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Schedule within a few days after ERCP to prevent recurrence of CBD stones.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident misdiagnoses as simple cholelithiasis
dynamic_flow.reply: May perform cholecystectomy without clearing CBD leading to retained stones.
Helps detect stones and guide management during cholecystectomy.
Monitor liver enzymes; manage transient pancreatitis from ERCP if it occurs.
Importance of completing cholecystectomy and recognizing symptoms of recurrence.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of choledocholithiasis using laboratory markers and imaging
Role of MRCP/EUS and ERCP in diagnosis and therapy
Timing of ERCP relative to cholecystectomy
Recognition of complications if stones are not removed
Use of intraoperative cholangiography and patient education
